text:
It is requested that any suggestions for the improvement of this List and any information which would render it more complete or accurate may be forwarded to the Author, at Ootacamund, before November next.

OOTACAMUND,
20th April 1880.

A. COTTERELL TUPP.
THE INDIAN CIVIL SERVICE LIST,
FOR 1880,

CONTAINING

(1) A COMBINED LIST FOR ALL PRESIDENCIES ACCORDING TO DATE OF APPOINTMENT,
(2) PROVINCIAL LISTS ACCORDING TO SENIORITY FOR PROMOTION IN THE PROVINCE,
(3) APPOINTMENT LISTS ACCORDING TO NATURE OF APPOINTMENTS HELD,
(4) DISTRIBUTION LISTS ACCORDING TO STATIONS AND DEPARTMENTS,
(5) SERVICE LISTS GIVING THE RECORD OF SERVICES, AND
(6) LISTS OF ALL CIVILIANS WHO HAVE DIED AND RETIRED SINCE 1857,

WITH VARIOUS OTHER LISTS AND APPENDICES,

BY

ALFRED COTTERELL TUPP, B.A.; F.S.S.;
BENGAL CIVIL SERVICE,
Offg. Accountant General, Madras.

MADRAS:
PRINTED AND PUBLISHED AT THE LAWRENCE ASYLUM PRESS, MOUNT ROAD.

1880.

Price, Rs. 6.
[All rights are reserved.]
ABSTRACT OF CONTENTS.

Combined List ........................................... 1—106
Provincial Lists ......................................... 107—296
Appointment Lists ....................................... 297—348
Distribution Lists ....................................... 350—376
Salary List .................................................. 377—383
Establishment Lists ...................................... 385—390
Average Salaries and Rates of Pay .................... 391—392
Deaths and Retirements .................................. 393—414
Service Lists ................................................ 416—571
Appendices .................................................. i—xlv
Index .......................................................... xlvii—lxxxv
PREFACE.

My design in compiling this work has been to collect into a single volume all the current facts with regard to the Indian Civil Service which could ordinarily be required. The accepted division of the Service into Bengal, Bombay and Madras, though still convenient for some purposes, and necessary as long as the Funds exist in their present shape, is antiquated, and generally useless, as a Bombay Civilian may serve in the Panjáb or Lower Bengal, a Madras Civilian at Simla and a Bengal Civilian in Madras or Bombay (as is now the case). I have therefore as much as possible ignored the distinction of Bengal, Bombay and Madras Services, and have treated all three as one great Indian Civil Service having the same prospects, conditions, origin and constitution.

It is by this name alone that the Service is known in England, and it has the great advantage of representing the unity and identity of the whole service which the use of the three separate names impliedly denies. Taking the Service all over India as one corporate body I have tried to give with regard to each member of it all the facts which are necessary to show (1) if he be still a member—his position and standing in the service, his locality, pay, and past services or (2) if he have died or retired—the date and place of the death and the date of the retirement.

For this purpose I have compiled the following lists:

(1) a Combined List.
(2) a Provincial List.
(3) an Appointment List.
(4) a Distribution List.
(5) a Salary List.
(6) an Establishment List.
(7) a Service List.

all but the 1st and 5th of these are arranged according to the nine Provinces into which India is divided.

(1) The Combined List shows in one list arranged according to the order of passing the Final Examinations (whether at Haileybury or with the Civil Service Commissioners) all the Civilians now in the Service. In the first portion containing those Civilians who were appointed from Haileybury I have (from want of further information) only been able to give the Civilians in the order in which they stand in each year in each Presidency with their number in that year, their province, pay and appointments (with dates).

In the second portion containing those Civilians who have been appointed under the Competition system I have arranged the names in the exact order in which they stood at the Final Examinations in England and have included all those who have
either died or retired, their names being given in Italics. This arrangement was not a matter so easy as would at first sight seem probable; for, as is always the case in dealing with any large number of persons, the most unexpected freaks and irregularities appear occasionally.

Thus the O. S. Commissioners for three or four years (1868-70) arranged the selected candidates not (as they were bound to do, in my opinion, by their own regulations, if not by law) according to the results of the Final Examination only, but according to the total number of marks obtained in all the Examinations after the open Competition. This list was accepted by the Provincial Governments and the Civilians now rank for seniority in accordance with it; but I am unable to find in the regulations any authority for such an arrangement, and I have accordingly in the Combined list ranked these Civilians according "to their position at the Final Examination" as prescribed in the published regulations.

Then again several Civilians have passed in the Open Competition and failed in the Final Examination, have then begun all over again and succeeded in passing both examinations, coming out to India four years after their names first appear in the Examination lists. Others have been prevented by ill-health and other causes from passing the Final Examination in the year when their contemporaries did so, and have finally passed a year later; or have only been admitted to the list of successful candidates much later than others owing to the death or resignation of some of those above them. In this case also they have generally been allowed to come out to India a year later than those who passed the open Competition with them.

These variations make the Combined list no easy one to compile; but I believe that as it has been done three or four times over, and has been carefully checked subsequently, it is nearly as accurate as it is possible to make it. I have excluded from this list all those who, though they passed the Final Examinations, did not proceed to India, as they can hardly be said to have belonged to the Indian Civil Service since they never joined it. The only exception that I have discovered is Mr. A. W. Hume, (No. 290) of 1863 whose name was included by mistake and the error discovered too late for correction. He did not come out to India in the Service; but, as far as I am aware or can ascertain, all the other Civilians whose names are included in this list actually landed in India and joined their appointments.

The Combined List therefore shows the exact relative position held by each Civilian to all others; and gives the names of all Civilians of all Provinces and Presidencies in one general list. The Combined List gives in the case of each Competition Civilian (1) his number in the Combined list (2) his number in the Final Examination of his year (3) his number in the open Competitive Examination of his year; (if the Civilian did not pass the open Competition along with the others who came out to India in his year, this column is left blank,) (4) his name in full (in the case of Oriental members, I have corrected the spelling of the names (when necessary) according to the Jonesian system) (5) his Degree or Degrees: (6) his University and College or, where he was not at any College, his School. When this column is blank,
it shows that the member was privately educated or only at private schools; all schools which are not purely private schools are entered. The Colleges and Schools are taken from the C. S. Commissioners' reports up to 1863 inclusive, and after that from the lists sent out to the Government of India by the C. S. Commissioners, so that they may be relied on as accurate; (7) his Province i.e. the Province to which he is actually attached at the present time; where Bombay and Madras Civilians are serving under the Government of India, I have entered Bo. C. S. and M. C. S. under the word "India." (8) his salary i.e. his total pay including acting allowances (9) his appointments i.e. both substantive and officiating, but the necessity of saving space has generally compelled me to give the date of only the most recent appointment.

(2.) The Provincial Lists.—In these lists I have taken the local Gradation Civil Service List of the Province and have excluded from it all those who no longer hold a substantive appointment in that province, so that the list may show the exact order of Civilians for promotion by seniority in the province. In other respects the provincial lists are exactly re-printed except that I have reduced the length of the entries under the column of "Remarks" wherever I found it possible to do so.

The list No. 1 of those Civilians serving under the Government of India is entirely original as it has never been published, I believe that all the other entries may be depended on as complete; but I found it impossible in some instances to trace what leave had been taken during service. It is corrected up to about the 15th March. Most of the other provincial lists had to be printed early in February and in the more distant provinces they do not profess to be corrected up to a later date than the 1st January but that of Madras is corrected up to March 1st and a good many corrections have been made in the N.W.P. list also up to about March 1st. In future years I hope to reprint the Provincial lists directly I receive them, and have the whole work out by the end of January.

(3) The Appointment Lists.—These lists contain the names of all the Civilians who are comprised in the Provincial lists re-arranged according to the nature of the appointments they hold.

They represent the Civilian portion of parts III to XVI of the ordinary Civil lists.

In these again the first part relating to the Government of India is original and will I hope be found useful as it was not available before. In the 2nd, or Lower Bengal, portion I have had to condense considerably as it was much more detailed than those of other Provinces.

It may be necessary to notice that in the Non-Regulation Provinces like the Punjab, the Appointment list differs from the Provincial list in giving the Civilians classified under each kind of appointment instead of by strict seniority. The latter principle prevails so generally that at first sight each list might seem to be a reprint of the other, but it is not so. In the Provincial lists some of the Non-Regulation Governments arrange Civilians according to a system of provincial seniority, the principle of which is not stated; but I presume that the rank is determined by the date of passing the Provincial Higher Standard of Examination. I am not aware on what
authority the seniority of Civilians among themselves is decided by these examinations, as in all Regulation Provinces the rank in the Provincial list is determined by the order of passing the Final Examination in England; and under the Act of Parliament constituting the Competition Service, this latter examination is the only one which is recognized as determining rank in the Service, (Section 32, 21 and 22 Vict. Cap. 106).

(4) The Distribution Lists.—These lists show under each Province the Divisions and Districts into which it is divided with the Civilians who are posted at each station. In the 1st part, the Government of India, the distribution is of course according to Departments as there are no local sub-divisions; but I have shown in this section, under the head of each place, what officers of the Government of India are actually serving there now. In Regulation Provinces I have given the Judge, Magistrate, Joint Magistrate and Assistant Magistrate of each district and in the Non-Regulation Provinces the Deputy Commissioner, Judicial Assistant, Assistant Commissioner and Settlement Officers (if any). The Commissioners of Divisions are given in both cases in the first column on the left hand. A list of the Officers at Head Quarters is given before each Provincial Distribution list and officers who do not belong to any particular district are included in this list.

In Bombay the Sub-Divisions are more numerous and I have given the Judge, Assistant Judge, Collector, 1st Assistant Collector, 2nd Assistant Collector, and Assistant Collector of each district. In Madras I have added to the divisions usual in Northern India those of Head Assistant Collector (answering to 2nd grade Joint Magistrate) and Special Assistant, the latter being confined to five districts. There are Commissioners of Divisions in Bombay but none in Madras; while there is a Board of Revenue in Madras but none in Bombay; in Bengal and the N. W. P. there are of course both classes of officers: the Members of the Board are shown in the list of officers at Head Quarters.

The whole of these Distribution lists are compiled in an original form, which I think has the advantage of clearness and compactness, although the information was previously available in various forms in the different Civil lists.

(5.) The Salary List—In this List I have thrown together the names of all the Civilians throughout India who draw a salary of Rs. 2,000 a month or more: and have shown with regard to each, (1) his number on the list, (2) his name, (3) his pay including officiating allowances, (4) his province to which he is at present attached, (5) his year of entry into the Service and (6) his present appointment.

I have fixed the limit at 2,000 Rs. because this includes all the higher officials such as Judges and Magistrates (except 2nd and 3rd grade) and it was useless rearranging according to salaries the great majority of the Service which receives well known salaries as Joint Magistrates, Assistant Magistrates, &c.

(6.) The Establishment Lists.—These lists are intended to show the strength of the Establishment of Civilians serving under each Government in India. Each list gives the number of officers of each designation serving under that parti-
cular Government with the amount of their salaries: it does not represent the sanctioned strength of establishment; but gives the number of officers actually serving under each Government on the 1st of January 1880.

These numbers are, it will be seen—

I. Government of India ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... 63
II. Lower Bengal ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... 214
III. N. W. P. ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... 194
IV. Panjab ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... 92
V. Central Provinces ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... 27
VI. Assam ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... 23
VII. British Barmah ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... 27
VIII. Madras ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... 160
IX. Bombay ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... 148

Total 943

The total number of Civilians serving in India is given at the end of the Combined list, (p. 96) and also in Appendices IX & X as 917; the difference is due to some of the Civilians serving under the Government of India having been reckoned again in the lists of their own Presidency: the error was discovered too late to be rectified in this issue: there are really only 34 Civilians possessing substantive appointments under the Government of India.

The Establishment Lists are original and have not been published before.

(7.) The Table of Average Salaries of all Civilians of each year in each Province on the 1st January 1880. This table is an enlargement and continuation up to date of the table of Average salaries which I gave in my book on "The Indian Civil Service and the Competition system" in 1875.

The figures under each Year and Province represent the average salary of all the Civilians of that year who are actually serving in that province at the time: the last column gives the average of those averages, and shows the average pay of all the Civilians of each year throughout India.

The table shows some curious results: for instance in the column of Average of all India, it will be seen that the pay is highest in 1846, viz., Rs. 4,833, and is higher in 1846 and 1847 than in 1844 and 1845, in 1848 it sinks suddenly to only 2,729 Rs. and then rises in 1849 to 3,708 Rs. and in 1850 to Rs. 3,852, both of which are higher than those of 1844; these high rates in 1849-50 are caused by the salaries of Members of Council. Again in 1852, it is 3,956 Rs. or a higher rate than any of the previous years except 1846-7. It then keeps at about 3,000 Rs. from 1853 to 1856: in 1857 it drops to 2,700 Rs. and remains at that rate during 1858 and 1859.

From 1860 it decreases rapidly and steadily from 2,251 Rs. in that year to 1,709 Rs. in 1863, but in 1864 it rises again to 1,799 Rs. owing to an appointment of Rs. 2,583 in the Central Provinces: it falls suddenly in 1865 to 1,162 Rs. and then rises again in
1867 to Rs. 1,392 owing to two appointments on Rs. 2,000 in that year in the North Western Provinces and Bombay. In 1868 it falls to Rs. 1,013 and in 1869 to Rs. 927 whence it rises in 1870 to Rs. 969 owing to one appointment of 2,000 Rs. having fallen to that year in British Barmah. From 1871 it decreases steadily from 878 Rs. in that year to Rs. 404 in 1879. It may be interesting, to know that the average pay of all Civilians in all India, from 1844 to 1879 is Rs. 2,140 per mensem. If we compare the salaries in different Provinces in the same year, we find great variations. Thus beginning from 1850 at which time the numbers of Civilians still remaining in the list first commence to be sufficiently large to give a fair average per province, it will be seen that while India is Rs. 6,666 and Madras nearly Rs. 4,000, the N. W. P. and Bombay are only Rs. 3,000 and Bengal is only 2,500 Rs. On the other hand in 1856 India is only 2,791, while the Panjab is 3,222 and Bengal and Bombay about 2,900, Madras being 2,500 and the N. W. P. only 2,200. Later on, in the years when such large numbers of Civilians were sent to Northern India, the figures are as follows: In 1861 India is 2,500, Madras 2,333, Bengal 2,069 and Bombay 2,000 while the N. W. P. and Panjab are only 1,892 and 1,785 respectively. In 1862 India is again 2,500 while Bombay and Madras run it close with 2,436 and 2,335; but Bengal, N. W. P. and Panjab decrease in that order, being 1,880, 1,526 and 1,477. The five provinces which are really similarly constituted (the Government of India and the smaller provinces being exceptional) are Bengal, N. W. P., Panjab, Bombay and Madras, and these, in the years regarding which there has been so much controversy, seem to be situated as follows: from 1861 to 1863 (all years given are to be considered inclusive) Madras is much the best off with 2,333, 2,385, and 1,834, Bombay comes next with 2,009, 2,436 and 1,724, Lower Bengal third with 2,069, 1,880 and 1,635, the N. W. P. fourth with 1,892, 1,526 and 1,280, and the Panjab last with 1,785, 1,477 and 1,595.

But in 1864 a great change occurs and the Panjab jumps up to first place with 2,000, Bombay being second with 1,728 and Bengal third with 1,672, Madras is fourth with 1,169 and N. W. P. last with 900. The 2,000 in the Panjab is so very high that I am rather afraid there may have been some mistake in the calculations; but I have no books at present with me so I cannot verify them. In 1865 the order is Bombay 1st, Bengal 2nd, Panjab 3rd, N. W. P. 4th and Madras 5th, so that it may be given as a general conclusion that from 1861 to 1863 Madras is the best off, and the Panjab and N. W. P. are the worst off; and in 1864 and 1865 the Panjab and Bombay are the best off and Madras and the N. W. P. are the worst off. Up to 1864 Bombay is always second and Lower Bengal third among these Provinces, but in 1865 Bombay is first and Lower Bengal second.

From 1867 to 1870 Madras is worse off than the N. W. P. or Bengal; but from 1870 onwards Madras is better off than the N. W. P.

(8) The Rate of Pay Table shows the number and the percentage of Civilians in each Province who are drawing each rate of pay at intervals of 500 Rs.; from those who draw 500 Rs. or under, to those who draw more than 3,500 Rs., of whom there are only 54 in all India.
The total number of each grade in all India is:

| Grade          | No. | Percentage |
|----------------|-----|------------|
| Not above 500  | 137 | 14·4       |
| 500 to 1,000   | 289 | 30·4       |
| 1,000 to 1,500 | 121 | 12·8       |
| 1,500 to 2,000 | 104 | 11·0       |
| 2,000 to 2,500 | 167 | 17·6       |
| 2,500 to 3,000 | 45  | 4·7        |
| 3,000 to 3,500 | 32  | 3·4        |
| above 3,500    | 54  | 5·7        |

Total 949 100·0

It will be seen therefore that 30 per cent. or nearly one-third of all Civilian salaries are between 500 and 1,000; that 24 per cent. or nearly one-fourth are between 1,000 and 2,000; and 22 per cent. or nearly one-fourth are between 2,000 and 3,000; the remaining one-sixth consists of 14 per cent. below 500 and of 10 per cent. above 3,000; so that, taking the totals, 10 per cent. are above 3,000; 32 per cent. are above 2,000; 55 per cent. are above 1,000; and 86 per cent. are above 500.

(9) (10) and (11).—The Lists of the Members of the Bengal, Madras and Bombay Services who have retired or died since 1857.

These lists contain the name of every member of the Service who has retired or died since 1857, so far as I have been able to ascertain them. I have compiled them from the original Service Gradation lists, and I have every reason to believe them complete and accurate; but, in some few instances, I have been unable to ascertain the date of death or retirement.

I have commenced the list from 1857, as that year is a landmark in the history of the services, both from the occurrence of the Mutiny, and from the fact that it was the first year in which the Members appointed by Competition took up their duties as Civilians, although a few had landed in India at the end of 1856. In Bengal in 1857, I have distinguished those who were killed in the Mutiny by an asterisk, and it will be seen that thirty names are so marked. I hope in a future issue to give the dates of entry into the Service of all those who have retired or died; but I was unable to ascertain them in time for this issue.

The very large number who retired in Bengal in 1877, the year when the graded pensions were granted, will be noticed; they amount to 36 as against from 10 to 15 in an ordinary year.

These death and retirement lists are original and have been somewhat difficult and laborious to compile; but I hope they will be found useful, as the information, even with regard to any one man, was only to be found before by hunting up old Civil Lists, and the search often ended in disappointment, as the lists of casualties were very imperfectly compiled.
In Part XII. I have given an abstract of these lists which shows the number of Civilians who retired and died in each year in each Presidency, and the total for all India.

It will be seen that the total varies from 69 in 1857 and 58 in 1877 to 19 in 1870, but the former were abnormal years on account of the Mutiny and of the special retirements. The highest of the normal years is 50 in 1863, so that the number of deaths and retirements in the whole Indian Civil Service in a normal year may be said to vary between 20 and 50. The average of the 21 normal years from 1858 to 1879 inclusive (but excluding 1877) is 34·4; and the rate of recruitment, when taken over long periods, and as long as the Service remains at its present strength, should no doubt be about 35 per annum. The actual rate of recruitment since 1865 (inclusive) has been 33·8, and, as the losses have been 34·4, they have almost exactly balanced one another. It will be seen that the total number of Civilians stood at 909 in 1865 and is now 917: the slight difference is due to the average losses having been calculated from 1858, while the average recruitment has been taken from 1865, the years between 1858 and 1865 having been periods of abnormally large recruitment.

The proportion of Deaths to Retirements in any Presidency is of course very various: thus in Bengal in 1860 there were 22 retirements to 6 deaths, while in 1862 there were only 3 retirements to 7 deaths. In 1871 there were 16 retirements to 2 deaths, while in 1876 there were only 6 retirements to 12 deaths; this last variation was however probably caused by Civilians postponing their retirement in 1876 on account of the proposed scheme for the acceleration of promotion which many thought would include a bonus to retiring members.

Part XIII contains a complete History of the Services of all Civilians, as far as I have been able to obtain them.

Division I.—The Government of India is entirely original as the Services of these officers have not been published before; the earlier portions of their services have been taken from the Provincial Service Lists of the Provinces to which they belonged previous to their transfer to the Government of India; and the latter portion has been compiled by myself from the various Gradation lists. The record is by no means complete; but it is the best that is available until the Services are published officially. I have had to omit entirely many officers who are serving under the Government of India merely because I could find no record of their Services.

Divisions II (Bengal), III (N.W.P.), and IV (Punjab) are taken from the published Provincial Lists of Services; but are very much abbreviated and reduced in bulk by the omission of all unimportant matter and by the use of abbreviations for all well known words. Even with this precaution the total Services occupy 157 pages of the work, and if the reduction in bulk had not been made they would have occupied at least 250 pages. The Madras List of Services has been reprinted as it was, because it was standing ready in type; but next year (if this work is re-published) it will be reduced like the others.

I trust that the omissions and abbreviations will not be found objectionable in any way. I have omitted (1) all privilege leave, as it does not affect service, (2) all subsidiary leave, (3) all short periods of absence without leave up to 10 days, and (4) all promotions to and reversions from Joint Magistracies or different grades of Joint
Magistracies, when not exceeding three months. These are I think quite unimportant, and their omission has enabled me to reduce the bulk of some records very considerably.

The British Barmah List of Services reached me just as this part of the book was going to Press and is re-printed with the usual abbreviations.

The only two Provinces in which I have been unable to obtain any list of Services are Assam and the Central Provinces. I have consequently been able to give a record of Services only of those Civilians who were previously in the N. W. P. and whose records were available from that Provincial list. I hope to be able to obtain Service lists of these Provinces before next year, if they are being compiled.

Appendices.—I now come to the Appendices about which much need not be said as the headings explain themselves. Appendix I, the diagram of the supply of Civilians, illustrates, I think, forcibly the irregularity of that supply during the earlier years of the Competition system: since 1865 it has been much more regular, and the inconveniences produced by the earlier want of system will no doubt not be felt in future. Appendices II and III are continuations up to date of the similar tables which I published in my work on the Indian Civil Service in 1875. They give all the figures and details with regard to recruitment and to losses by death and retirement, and will I hope prove useful.

Appendix IV gives the College or School of each Civilian and this is the first time I have been able to give a table of this kind complete up to date, as the C. S. Commissioners ceased to publish these data from 1864. I have however now obtained them from the lists sent out by the Secretary of State to the Indian Governments, and I think it will be admitted that no greater refutation is possible of Col. G. Chesney’s ill-founded and inaccurate statement, that the University and Public School men among the Competition Civilians are “mere waifs and strays.” Colonel Chesney said (Edinburgh Review, April 1874) “practically the English Universities contribute no candidates to the Competition”; how many “candidates” they contribute I do not know, nor does Colonel Chesney, as the Colleges of the unsuccessful competitors are not given anywhere; but this table will prove how many of the successful competitors are University men, even in the narrow sense of the term as used by Colonel Chesney of the English Universities only.

It will be seen from this table that of 903 men appointed to the Service from 1856 to 1879, 157 were at Oxford and 107 at Cambridge so that in the narrowest sense of the term 264 or nearly one-third were University men, if to these be added the other English, Scotch and Irish Universities we obtain a total of 618 out of 903, who

| Location          | Number |
|-------------------|--------|
| Oxford            | 157    |
| Cambridge         | 107    |
| Dublin            | 111    |
| London            | 102    |
| Queen's, Ireland  | 49     |
| Edinburgh         | 50     |
| Aberdeen          | 27     |
| Glasgow           | 7      |
| St. Andrews       | 8      |

are bonâ fide University men. If a proportion of more than two-thirds can fairly be called “mere waifs and strays in the list,” then Colonel Chesney is right; but if not, it would have been perhaps better had he ascertained the facts accurately and carefully before making so reckless and misleading an assertion, as he did when he stated that “scarcely any one ever comes up from the different Universities and Colleges of the
kingdom for these great prizes” (p. 342, Edin. Rev., April 1874). If we analyse the whole table we find that the proportion of candidates educated at the various classes of institutions is as follows:

| Institution                  | Number |
|------------------------------|--------|
| English Universities         | 366    |
| Scotch                       | 92     |
| Irish                        | 160    |
| Foreign                      | 14     |
| Total Universities           | 632    |
| Public Schools               | 140    |
| Private Colleges             | 14     |
| Grammar Schools              | 68     |
| Total at Colleges and Public Schools | 854 |
| At private Schools           | 49     |
| Grand Total                  | 903    |

Percentage of those educated at Colleges and Private Schools to total number appointed ... 94.6

It will I think hardly be believed, after all that has been said to the contrary that 95 per cent. of all the Competition Civilians who have come to India have been educated at a University, College, or Public School; but of the fact there can be no doubt. The figures are taken from the official returns compiled by the C. S. Commissioners, and the only point on which there can be any difference of opinion is as to which schools are to be reckoned public schools and which are not; but I think my list will be accepted as a fair one, and I have included all Grammar Schools, as they are really public schools as opposed to proprietary schools. It may therefore be said with confidence that 95 per cent. of the Competition Civilians have been educated at a University, College, Public School or Grammar School, and only 5 per cent. at private schools and by private tuition. If this be the case, surely all the ill-founded statements, about the Service being supplied chiefly from the cramming institutions, and about the “University and Public School system being wrong, if the system of selection for the Indian Civil Service is right”* may be consigned to the oblivion they deserve; for the two systems, thus absurdly contrasted, are now shown to be almost absolutely identical.

Appendix V gives all the details with regard to the University Degrees obtained by Civilians in each year, and Appendix VI gives an abstract of the figures so arrived at. I think that the percentage of Graduates shown will create some surprise and yet, as I have remarked in the foot-note to this Appendix, it is by no means complete, for it is impossible in many cases to ascertain the degrees. It will be seen that from 1856 to

* Col. Chesney, Edin. Rev., April 1874.
1860 the number of graduates never fell below 50 per cent., that out of the 22 years, it was over 40 per cent. in 9 years and over 30 per cent. in 15 years, while the average for the whole 22 years is 37 per cent. The figure of 36 per cent. given at the bottom column is inclusive of the year 1879, about which my information is very imperfect as yet, but from 1856 to 1878 the average of graduates is 37 per cent. or somewhat more than a third of all the Civilians. The only years in which the percentage sank below 20 are 1869 and 1877. If those who possess degrees and are not mentioned in the Appendix V will kindly inform me of the fact, I am sure that the results will be even more favourable than they are now.

The total number of Graduates of each kind is as follows:

| Degree       | Number |
|--------------|--------|
| B. A.        | 191    |
| M. A.        | 99     |
| LL. B.       | 13     |
| LL. D.       | 10     |
| D. C. L.     | 4      |
| Other Degrees| 8      |

Total... 325

Appendix VII gives all the honorary distinctions which have been awarded to members of the Service, and I have added the names of those who are Fellows of Learned Societies, as far as I have been able to ascertain them; but I have no doubt that there are many more. As many of the distinctions in different orders are possessed by the same person, there are not so many as 115 Civilians who are décoré and the number will hardly be considered large.
Appendix VIII. gives the names and marks of the first and second man in each year both at the open Competitions and at the Final Examinations; and where there are 60 appointments the first three are given, and where 80 the first four; so as to maintain a proportion of 5 per cent. of the whole. It will be noted in the open Competitions that in 1859 Mathematics was raised from 1,000 to 1,250, and Sanskrit and Arabic from 375 to 500; in 1867 the number of marks (1,000) awarded to English literature was divided into 500 for literature and 500 for History, and the marks for Sanskrit were reduced from 500 to 375. In 1869 Sanskrit was put back to 500, and Natural Science was increased from 500 to 1,000.

In July 1878 the first examination under the new system of enforced attendance at a University, great changes were made. English Composition, History and Literature were reduced from 500 to 300 each, Greek was reduced from 750 to 600 and Latin increased from 750 to 800. French and German were augmented from 375 to 500, while Italian was raised from 375 to 400, Mathematics was lowered from 1,250 to 1,000, and Natural Science from 1,000 to 600, being also divided into Electricity, &c., 300 and Mechanics, &c., 300; Moral Science was reduced from 500 to 300 and was confined to Logic. There has not been time as yet to see what the effects of these changes will be. I append the names of the first men in each subject in the whole 24 years, with their marks and the Maximum, but the fixed deduction of 125 must of course be taken into account after 1863.

Appendix IX shows the number of Civilians employed in each Province and Presidency. It will be seen that Bengal has exactly twice as many as Madras and Bombay put together, 611 against 306, and I think this great disproportion shows the anachronism of keeping up the three services separate. The Bengal service now really furnishes officers for all India except the Regulation districts of the Madras and Bombay Presidencies. As regards the Provinces, Lower Bengal has the largest staff 214, and the N.W.P. the next 194, both these, which are mere sub-divisions of the Bengal service, being larger than the whole Presidencies of Madras (160) and Bombay (146). The Non-Regulation Provinces and the Government of India have from 92 down to 23.

Appendix X gives the number of Civilians of each year of entry who are still left in the Service. Of 1840 there is only 1 and of 1843 and 1844 only 2 each. The numbers then mount steadily except that there are only 3 left of 1848, till we come to 1852 which has only 7. After this the number is regulated chiefly by the original supply in that year.

The large years are 1856—31  
1857—45  
1861—53  
1862—50  
1863—69  
1864—44

After 1864 there are never more than 40 in any year; but in the three years 1861, 1862—3 there are in Bengal still 122 members of the Service, or one-fifth of the whole (611). Madras has 57 Civilians in 1862—3—4 alone out of a total of 160; and Bombay has 48 in 1867—8—9—70, out of a total of 146. The blocks in the respective
services occur therefore in the latter of these years in 1862—3 in Bengal; in 1863—4 in Madras and in 1869—70 in Bombay; and it might be well if the overflowing years of one Presidency could feed the scanty years of another, so as to equalize promotion to some extent throughout India.

Appendices XI and XII show the respective numbers of Haileybury and Competition Civilians in the three Presidencies and 9 Provinces, at each period of 5 years from 1860 to 1880, and also in 1858, the earliest year for which I could obtain data. Dealing only with totals for all India, it will be seen that there were in 1858, 798 Haileybury Civilians to 52 Competition ones; by 1860 there was but little change, the numbers being 750 to 67.

But by 1865 a great change had occurred, and they were then 547 to 362 or $1\frac{1}{2}$ to 1: by 1870 the Competition Civilians had exceeded the Haileybury in number, and were 498 to 418. By 1875 the proportions were 661 to 295, or more than two to one; and by 1880 this had increased to 750 to 167 or $4\frac{1}{2}$ to 1.

In Appendix XIII I have distinguished the Haileybury and Competition Civilians from one another in the only years when they are mixed up together, viz., 1856 and 1857 in Bengal and Bombay. In Madras the Haileybury Civilians end in 1857 and the Competition do not begin till 1860.

In Appendix XIV, and last, I have shown the number of Civilians who were in the service in each Presidency in each year from 1857 to 1880. It will be seen that the total has varied but little in the 23 years; it was 886 in 1857 and is 917 now. It rose to its highest point 968 in 1873 and fell to its lowest 802 in 1861.

In Bengal it has increased from 553 in 1857 to 611 in 1880 owing to the absorption into that Presidency of the Non-Regulation Provinces; but Madras has decreased from 185 to 160 and Bombay from 148 to 146.

The largest number in Bengal was 644 in 1877 and the smallest 494 in 1861.

The largest number in Madras was 196 in 1865 and the smallest 153 in 1862.

The largest number in Bombay was 175 in 1874 and the smallest 126 in 1863.

I have now explained and illustrated as far as I was able all the parts of the book, and the Appendices, and I need only speak of a few topics of a more general nature.

(1) Spelling.—As regards the spelling of the names of places, I have followed the Jonesian or scientific system absolutely, and have not attempted any compromise, which, though it may be suitable for official works intended for all classes of readers, is very unsatisfactory, unscientific, and ill-adapted for the members of a highly educated service who will be the chief readers of this book. In Northern India, I believe, I have been able to give the names with accuracy; in Bombay I have sometimes been doubtful; in Madras the corruptions from the native names are so astounding, that they assume the form of wholly different words, and it is necessary to give a more or less imperfect transliteration in order that the word may be recognizable as the same. In Barmah I have not ventured to interfere with the spelling, except in the case of a few well-known names; but it is now evidently totally unsystematic.

(2) Corrections—I have corrected up to the latest date practicable and have made many alterations while the book was passing through the Press; the Combined
list is corrected up to the 25th March and should be referred to in all cases where the latest information is required.

The Provincial and Appointment Lists are chiefly reprinted from the Civil Lists of the 1st of January, but corrections have been made wherever it was possible. The lists of Services have not been corrected up to a later date than that at which they have been published by the Local Governments, as I found the task an impossible one.

(3) Objects effected.—I hope that by uniting in one volume of moderate size the whole of the Civil Service portions of the Civil lists of 9 Provinces, and the lists of Services which form five separate volumes, besides giving much new and original matter, I shall have provided the members of the Service with a work which will be useful, (1) from its saving expense and bulk, as the same information could only be obtained before from 9 separate volumes, (2) from its concentrating in one volume all the Civilian portion of many volumes, the remainder of which was not required as a rule by Civilian readers, and (3) by its affording much information which was previously either not available at all, or was only attainable after long and troublesome searches.

(4) Delay in publishing.—I promised this work for the end of March, but I think I shall be excused for the delay of three weeks which has occurred, when it is remembered that this is a first attempt, and that it has been made under the constant pressure of very heavy official work. In future years, I hope to have the volume published by the end of January or early in February.

(5) Omissions.—I have been compelled by the great size the book was attaining to omit several of the portions which I promised in the Prospectus to include. These are chiefly,

(1) the Civilian portions of the Financial Codes.
(2) the Lists of the Services in former years.
and (3) the Regulations for Examinations, &c.

The printers had originally estimated that the portions of the book now published would occupy about 500 pages and I then hoped to have room for the above articles but when it was found that we had already got to 700 pages without any of them I was obliged to give up all hope of including them as the book would have swelled to 1,000 pages and would have been of unwieldy size.

As it is, it will be over 700 pages instead of 500, and I hope that on this account it will not be thought unreasonable that the price has been raised from five rupees to six. I hope to issue before long a small volume containing, (1) the Civilian portion of the Financial Codes, corrected up to date, (2) the Regulations for all Examinations connected with the Service, and (3) the latest editions of the rules of the three Civil Funds. This will, I think, constitute a useful Civilians' Manual and will form a supplement to the present work. I hope that it may be ready in three or four months time; and I shall then have before me only one portion of the task which I hope some day to accomplish, viz.,—a sketch of the History of the Indian Civil Service from its first origin.
(6). Subscriptions. In the nine weeks which have elapsed since the issue of my Prospectus of this work, I have received 315 promises of subscription, including the different Governments, to the issue of this year; and I think I may fairly hope that 200 more Civilians will take the book; but comparatively very few of those who have subscribed this year have promised to take the work regularly, so that I am still quite in uncertainty as to whether I shall be able to continue the publication annually. I think that considering the very great number of alterations which occur in a large Service like the Indian Civil Service, a year would be the longest interval at which the work could be published with any advantage: if it were published more seldom than this, it might have an historical interest, but could hardly be of much use as a current work for reference.

In conclusion I would beg the utmost indulgence for this first attempt at compiling a work which I would fain hope will be useful but which contains many thousands of entries and dates, every one of which is liable to error in all the four stages of its career, in the hands of the compiler, of the copyist, of the compositor, and of the reader of proofs. I have read all the proofs myself, except portions of the Provincial and of the Service lists, and every portion of the Book has been carefully read three times in proof, in revise and in final revise by an M. A. of the Madras University, whom I have employed to assist me in this compilation: but I know too well that in a work of this kind I cannot hope to have escaped a multitude of errors and I can only ask the indulgence of my readers for a first attempt, made amid the distractions of heavy official work, and interrupted occasionally by illness, and promise them that, if the support accorded to the work is sufficient to justify me in re-publishing it annually, I will do my best that each year shall see an improvement in the book and a step in advance towards that perfect accuracy which is so hopelessly unattainable in a work of this kind.

A. COTTERELL TUPP.

PART VIII.

Gradation List of

HER MAJESTY'S COVENANTED CIVIL SERVANTS.
The Rank of Civil Servants commences from the date of arrival at Madras of the first Civil Servant appointed in Europe, of the same season of which they are Civil Servants; and, being thus determined, all Civil Servants belong, under twelve years to Class V,—from the thirteenth to the end of the eighteenth year, to Class IV,—from the nineteenth to the end of the twenty-third year, to Class III;—from the twenty-fourth to the end of the thirty-first year, to Class II; and from and after the thirty-first year, to Class I.

Column 1, A denotes that the Officer has not passed either of the two Standards of qualification. B that the first or lower Standard has been passed, C that the Officer cannot take Special leave, and M that though not having passed by the 2nd Standard, nor holding an appointment superior to that of Assistant, he is invested permanently with the full powers of a Magistrate. F denotes Officers recalled from Furlough for Famine duty.

Column 2—(a) For Officers who entered the Madras Civil Service prior to 1867, Small Italics distinguish languages passed in College, Small Roman Capitals Minor rewards; Brevier Sansserif, Major reward.

(b) For Officers who entered the Madras Civil Service in and after 1867, Small Roman letters denote the languages passed in the first Standard Examination, and those of the second languages passed in the second Standard Examination (not being the vernacular of the District in which the Officer is serving). Small Italics shew the first language of the second Standard. Antique letters denote Special Tests. Large Roman Capitals, High Proficiency. Large Italic Capitals, Honors.

Column 3, The names printed in Italics denote that the Officers are on Furlough or special leave.

Column 6, Italics show Junior Furlough and sick leave without allowances under former Rules and extraordinary leave under the Civil Leave Code. Roman Capitals show Special Leave. Antique letters indicate a year of sick leave taken under rules in force before 1st July 1868, with reference to Section 11—(2) Civil Leave Code.

Column 7, The Active Service is calculated in accordance with Section 2, Civil Leave Code, and is the period of Residence qualifying for Pension under Section 4, Supplement A of the Civil Pension Code.*

IX.

Bombay.

GOVERNOR AND PRESIDENT IN COUNCIL.

His Excellency the Honourable Sir Richard Temple, Bart., G.C.S.I., C.I.E. Took his seat 1st May 1877. Pay Rs. 10,666-10-8, (gone to England.)

PERSONAL STAFF.

Charles Edward Buckland, B.A., B.C.S., Private Secretary. Pay Rs. 1,500. (Serving under the Government of India.)

MEMBERS OF COUNCIL.

The Honourable Lionel Robert Ashburner, C.S.I. Third Member. Took his seat on the 1st August 1877. Pay Rs. 5,333-5-4. Acting Governor.

The Honourable E. W. Ravenscroft, C.S.I. Fourth Member. Took his seat on the 15th April 1879. Pay Rs. 5,333-5-4.

The rank of Civil Servants commences from the date of arrival at Bombay of the first Writer appointed in Europe of the same season of which they are Writers; and being thus determined, all Civil Servants belong, during the first four years, to Class VI.;—from the fifth to the end of the eighth year, to Class V.;—from the ninth to the end of the twelfth year, to Class IV.;—from the thirteenth to the end of the twentieth year, to Class III.;—from the twenty-first to the end of the twenty-eighth year, to Class II.;—and from the twenty-ninth year, to Class I.

The date of commencement of Service is that of the Covenant, or of the Appointment by the Home Authority, whichever may be the earlier.

Those Civil Servants to whose names the letters JD are attached, are applicants for the Judicial Branch of the Service.

The letters A, G, Hin., H, K, M, P, S, Sin., T, Ur. and (1) or (2) prefixed to the names, signify that the parties have passed an examination in the Arabic, Gujarathi, Hindi, Hindustani, Kanarese, Marathi, Persian, Sanskrit, Sindhi, Telugu, and Urdu Languages, and the Lower or Higher Standards under the Examination Rules.

The letters specified in column 6 denote the date of return of officers from leave; M.C. medical certificate; P.A. private affairs; and F. furlough.

In the column of Emoluments S. stands for Salary; A.A. for Absentee allowance; D.A. Deputation allowance; T.A. Travelling allowance; S.A. Subsistence allowance; T. for Tentage; H. for House-rent; M. for Moonshee allowance; C.A. for Conveyance allowance, and N.P. for Net pay.

I

GOVERNMENT OF INDIA.

ROBERT BARCLAY CHAPMAN, c.s.l., (Barrister-at-Law).—Arrd 6th Mar 1850; Under Secy Govt of India, Home and Finance 15th Jan 1858, on Rs 1,250, also Offg in Forgn Dept 29th Jan 1858; Leave on M C 3 months from 8th July 1859; Fund for 3 years from 10th Apr 1860; Offg Mag Pabna, 21st Mar 1863, on Rs 1,298; Jr Secy Bd of Rev 1st July 1863, on Rs 2,000; Offg Secy Bd of Rev 24th June 1863, on Rs 2,333; Secy Bd of Rev 24th July 1863, on Rs 2,500; Offg Comr Nadia, 13th Nov 1866, on Rs 2,916; Offg Secy Govt of India Finl Dept 16th Jan 1869, on Rs 3,611; confirmed 17th Apr 1871, on Rs 4,166; furl 6 months from 3rd June 1874, returned 10th Dec 1874.

WILLIAM WATERFIELD.—Arrd 19th Nov 1852; Jt Mag 2nd gr 25th Mar 1857, on Rs 700; Supt 2nd or S Div of Survey 18th Apr 1857, on Rs 900; Offg Supt N Div of Survey 27th Apr 1858; 1st Asst Acct Genl Madras, 3rd Mar 1859, on Rs 1,000; Govt of India 9th Sep 1859, on Rs 1,500; Offg Acct Genl of Bengal 31st May 1860, on Rs 2,000; Offg Civil Auditor Madras, 10th Jan 1868, on Rs 2,000; Offg Dy Civil Auditor and Acct Genl Bengal 27th July 1861; on Rs 2000; leave for 3 months from 15th Nov 1862, Offg Civil Paymaster Bombay, on Rs 2,000; furl for 18 months from 14th May 1863; Civil Paymaster N W P 26th Nov 1864, on Rs 1,500; Offg Dy Acct Genl N W P 30th Nov 1864, on Rs 2,000; Dy Acct Genl, Offg Acct Genl N W P Pro, 5th July 1865, on Rs 2,000, Rs 2,450 from 1st Oct 1866; Acct Genl N W P, 14th June 1867, on Rs 2,500; furl for 19 months from 14th Apr 1873; returned 14th Nov 1874, on Rs 2,500; Offg Comptr Genl and Hd Comr of Currency 7th Mar 1877, on Rs 3,500; confirmed 3rd Jan 1880; furl 21st Apr 1880.

JAMES DAVIDSON GORDON, c.s.l.—Arrd 10th Nov 1854; Magt Monghyr, 25th Jan 1865; Offg Judge Purneah, 7th Apr 1865; Dinagepur, 15th May 1865; Murshidabad, 25th May 1865; Offg Collr of Customs Calcutta 30th June 1865; services placed at the disposal of the Govt of India, Home Dept 23rd Jan 1866; Judl Comr Maisur and Kurg, Chief Comr Maisur and Kurg, 1st May 1878.

JOHN DOUGLAS SANDFORD, (Bar-at-Law)—Arrd 22nd Oct 1856; Attd to Ben 12th Aug 1857; Asst Tipperah, Aug 1857; services placed at the disposal of Govt of India, Home Dept and attached to N W P Nov 1858; Asst Mag Fatehpur, 24th Dec 1858; Offg Asst Secy to Govt N W P 1st Apr 1859; confirmed, but Offg Under Secy 1st Sept 1859; confirmed Feb 1862; Offg Secy to Govt from 13th Dec 1862 to 19th Mar 1863; on spl duty as Ag Secy to the Police Comr from 6th June to 15th Aug 1863; Jr Secy to Govt N W P Sept 1864; Offg Regtr Sadr Diwani Nizamut Adalat N W P 8th Apr 1865; Jr Secy to Govt 18th Nov 1865; Offg Secy to Bd of Rev 18th Apr 1866; reverted 27th Sept 1866; Offg Regtr High Court, N W P 10th Jan 1867; confirmed 25th Mar 1867; furl to Eur 3rd Aug 1868; Regtr High Court 3rd Nov 1870; Offg Mag Azamgarh, 30th Apr 1871; services placed at the disposal of Govt of India, Home Dept Nov 1871; left N W P 9th Nov 1871; Judl Comr British Burmah, 30th Jan 1872; furl 21 months, 3rd May 1875; returned 2nd Feb 1877; Judl Comr Maisur, 8th Feb 1878.

FREDERICK HENVEY.—Arrd 31st Oct 1861; attd to N W P 30th Dec 1862; Asst Mag Muttra 16th Jan 1863; leave on med cer from 1st May to 21st Oct 864; transferred to Agra 6th May 1865; leave to Eur on private affairs from 10th July 1865 to 30th June 1866; Offg Under Secy to Govt N W P 9th July 1866; Offg Jt Mag 2nd gr Cawnpore, 12th Oct 1866; Offg Under Secy to Govt 5th May 1867; confirmed 24th July 1867; Offg Secy to Bd of Rev N W P 15th Sept 1868; Under Secy to Govt 25th Oct 1868, Offg Jr Secy 4th Nov 1868; Jt Mag 2nd gr, Offg Jr Secy to Govt 24th Sep 1869; Offg Secy 24th Feb 1870; Offg Jr Secy 21st Apr 1870; Offg Secy to Bd of Rev 2nd May 1870; Offg Jr Secy to Govt 16th Oct 1870; on spl duty for compiling a narrative of the Famine of 1869-70; Ist Apr 1871; furl to Eur from 2nd Dec 1871 to 27th Nov 1873; Offg Jr Secy to Govt N W P 16th Dec 1873; placed at disposal of G I July 1874; Offg Under Secy Foreign Dept 31st July 1874; confirmed 5th May 1875; Offg Resident Nepal 30th Dec 1876; Resident 3rd class Kashmir 16th May 1878.

JAMES WESTLAND.—Arrd 10th Oct 1862; Asst Mag Jessur 8th Dec 1862; Nadia, 17th Dec 1863; 24 Pargs 23rd May 1864; Comr Hazaribagh 8th Aug 1864; Offg Dy Comr Maubhura 27th Feb 1866; Offg Jt Mag 2nd gr Nadia 27th July 1866; on Rs 700, confirmed 23rd Mar 1867 on Rs 700, Offg Ist gr Nadia 5th May 1868 on Rs. 766, Offg
Mag Jessur 16th July 1868 on Rs 1,233; Offg 2nd gr 7th Sept 1869 on Rs 1,233, Offg Supt and Remr Legal Affairs 7th June 1870 on Rs 1,900, Under Secy to Govt of India Finl Dept 9th Dec 1870 on Rs 1,500, furl for 1 year 1st Apl 1872; Offg Acctt Genl Bengal 26th Mar 1873 on Rs 2,700; Dy Acctt Genl Madras, Offg Acctt Genl Bengal 27th Aug 1873 on Rs 2,166; Acctt Genl C P Nagpur 13th Nov 1873 on Rs 1,500, on spl duty Home Dept 1st Jan 1876; furl for 19 months from 10th Apl 1876; Inspr of Local Offices of Acctt 18th Oct 1877 on Rs 2,000; on Rs 2,500; 1st Apl 1878 Acctt Genl Bengal Offg Compr Genl and Hd Comr 26th July 1878 on Rs 3,000; Reverts 1st Oct 1878; Acctt Genl Ist el Bengal 30th Apl 1879, on Rs 3,000; Offg Comtr Genl and Hd Comr currency 14th Aug 1879 on Rs, 3,500; reverts 24th Oct 1879; to officiate as Comt Genl 21st Apl 1880 on Rs 3,500.

EDWIN FELIX THOMAS ATKINSON, B.A.—Arrd 21st Jan 1863; Attd to N W P 17th July 1863; Asst Magt Allahabad 3rd Aug 1863; Jaunpur 7th Sept 1864; Offg Jt Magt 2nd gr Jaunpur 13th Aug 1867; Offg Mag 2nd gr 12th Nov 1867 on Rs. 1,366; Asst Magt 5th Dec 1867; Offg Jt Magt 2nd gr 1st Jan 1868; Offg Magt 2nd gr 6th Aug 1878; on Rs 1,666; Offg Jt Mag 6th Oct 1878; Offg Judge S C Court Allahabad, 22nd De; 1868 on Rs 966; Offg Jt Mag 2nd gr Dehra Dun 4th Apl 1870; Jaunpur 28th Oct 1870; 1st gr 15th Apl 1871; Offg Judge S C Court Allahabad, 3rd May 1871 on Rs 966; compiler N W P Gazetteer 28th June 1872 on Rs 1,200; Offg Secy Bd of Rev N. W. P 8th Oct 1874 on Rs. 1,666; reverted 14th Nov 1874 on Rs. 1,200; again offd 10th Feb 1875; on Rs 1,666, reverted 28th Mar 1875 on Rs 1,200; furl 8th Apl 1876; resumed charge of Gazetteer 14th Feb 1877; Asst Acctt Genl, Offg Acctt Genl N W P 1st Mar 1877 on Rs 1,833; Dy Acctt Genl Bombay, Offg Acctt Genl N W P 28th Aug 1878 on Rs. 2,000; Acctt Genl N W P 1st Feb 1880 on Rs 2,250.

THOMAS WILLIAM RAWLINS.—Arrd 11th Jan 1863; Attd to N W Prov, Asst Magt Benares, 25th June 1864; Jaunpur, 3rd Feb 1864; Asst Magt Allahabad 18th Mar 1868; Offg Judge S C Court Allahabad, 23rd Mar 1868, on Rs 966; Asst Magt Allahabad 8th July 1870; Offg Jt Mag 2nd gr 29th Aug 1870; Offg Judge S C Court 31st Oct 1870 on Rs 966; Asst Mag 16th Nov 1870; Offg Jt Mag 2nd gr Allahabad, 2nd Apl 1871; Merath 17th Apl 1874; 1st gr 7th June 1871 on Rs 833; 2nd gr 25th Nov 1871; Asst Mag 5th Dec 1871; Offg Judge S C Court Allahabad, 29th Mar 1872 on Rs 966; confirmed 28th Nov 1872 on Rs 1,200; furl 1st Apl 1875; Judge S C Court Allahabad 9th Nov 1876 on Rs 1,200; Asst Acctt Genl Offg Acctt Genl Panjab, 6th Mar 1877 on Rs 1833; Asst Acctt Genl N W P, Offg Acctt Genl Panjab, 28th Aug 1878 on Rs 2000; Dy Acct Genl Madras, Offg Acct Genl Panjab, 30th Apl 1879 on Rs 2,000; Acctt Genl Panjab, on Rs 2,250, 1st Feb 1880.

ALFRED COTTERELL TUPP, B.A.—Arrd 29th Nov 1862; attd to N W Pro 9th Oct 1863; Asst Magt Allahabad, 1st Nov 1863; Fatehpur, 17th Nov 1864; on Spl duty in Mahoba case, 1st Dec 1867; Asst Magt Fatehpur, 1st June 1868; on Spl duty Nani Tal (for Fatehpur Memoir), 26th July 1869; Asst Magt Fatehpur, 8th Oct 1869; Offg Jt Magt 2nd gr 8th June 1870; Offg Magt 27th July 1870 on Rs 1,666; Offg Jt Magt 2nd gr 6th Oct 1870; Asst Magt 23rd Dec 1870; Offg Jt Magt 2nd gr and Judge S C C Dehra Dun, 7th Apl 1871; 1st gr 25th June 1871; 2nd gr 22nd Nov 1871; Asst Magt 1st Jan 1872; Offg Jt Magt 1st gr 7th May 1872; 2nd gr 8th June 1872; 1st gr 19th Aug 1872; 2nd gr 14th Nov 1872; Asst Magt 15th Feb 1873; Offg Jt Magt 1st gr 21st Apl 1873; Offg Jt Magt 1st gr Allahabad, 24th Oct 1873; 2nd gr 7th Nov 1873; furl 6th Apl 1874; Asst Magt Allahabad 18th Jan 1876; Offg Compiler Provl Gazetteer, N W P 16th Mar 1876, on Rs 966; Jt Magt 2nd gr offg Compiler 15th Apl 1877; Jt Magt 1st gr Azamgarh, 8th Aug 1877 on Rs 1,200; Offg Magt Azamgarh 7th May 1878 on Rs 1833; Jt Magt 1st gr 26th July 1878 on Rs 1,200; Asst Acct Genl Bengal, Offg Dy Acctt Genl Madras 31st Oct 1878 on Rs 1,500; Asst Acctt Genl Bengal, Offg Acct Genl Madras 25th Jan 1879 on Rs 2,000; Asst Acctt Genl N W P Offg Acctt Genl Madras, 30th Apl 1879 on Rs 2,000; Dy Acctt Genl, Offg Acctt Genl, Madras 1st Feb 1880.

DAVID MILLER BARBOUR, n. A.—Arrd 20th Dec 1863; Asst Mag Patna, 12th Apl 1864; Shahabad at Bhabna, 1st Aug 1856; Perhat at Madhubani, 9th July 1876; Offg Magt 1st gr 4th July 1868 on Rs 766; 2nd gr 22nd Jan 1869; Setamarhi 26th Jan 1869; Asst Magt Offg Jt Magt 2nd gr Hugli, 20th May 1869; Shahabad 15th Feb 1870; Patna 10th Jan 1871; Asst Magt Offg Magt 2nd gr Patna, 25th Apl 1871, on Rs 1,233; Asst Magt Jt Mag 2nd gr Baxar, 20th July 1871; Shahabad, 16th Nov 1871; Asst Mag Offg Und Secy Govt of India, Finl Dept 9th Mar 1872 on Rs 1,166; confirmed 27th Aug 1873, on Rs 1,300; furl 14 months 19th Oct 1874; retd 1st Dec 1875; Under Secy Govt of India, Offg Acct Genl Bengal, 23rd Feb 1877, on Rs 2,100; Under Secy
Govt of India, Offg Secy Govt of Bengal Finl Dept 2nd Apl 1878, on Rs 2,100; Gazd to Finl Dept 12th June 1877; Acct Genl Panjab, Offg Finl Secy Bengal 26th July 1878 on Rs 2,250; Acct Genl Panjab 12th June 1879 on Rs 2,350; furl for 19 months 5th May 1879; Acct Genl Madras, 1st Feb 1880.

CHARLES JAMES LYALL.—Arrd 4th Dec 1867; Attd to N W P 25th Oct 1867; Asst Mag Mirath, 19th Dec 1867; Bullandshahr, 1st Apl 1869; Offg Under Secy to Govt N W P 24th Feb 1870; Asst Mag Allahabad, 21st Apl 1870; Offg Under Secy to Govt N W P 1st Apl 1871; Asst Under Secy to Govt of India, Fogn Dept 1st Apl 1872; Offg Under Secy to Govt N W P 4th July 1872; Offg Jr Secy 31st Oct 1872; Offg Under Secy 12th Dec 1872; placed at the disposal of the Govt of India, Dept of Rev, Agrl, and Com Apl 1873; Left N W P 13th Apl 1873; Offg Under Secy Govt of India Rev, and, Agrl Dept 17th Apl 1873; confd 1st Oct 1873; furl 16½ months 18 Oct 1878.

JAMES WHITE.—Arrd 9th Dec 1868; Attd to N W P Dec 1868; Asst Mag Bijnor, 12th Jan 1869; Fatehpur 21st Mar 1872; serv placed at the disposal of the Govt of India, in the Foreign Dept for Pol employment in Rajputana Dec 1873; Left N W P 24th Dec 1873; Offg Pol Agt Jaipur, Ajmir 1st Jan 1874; Asst Mag Benares, 13th Dec 1875; to Moradabad, 3rd Feb 1876; Offg Dy Comr Ajmir, 12th May 1876; Asst Comr Ajmir and Pol Agt 3rd cl, 25th May 1877; furl 1st Apl 1880.

EDWARD JAMES SINKINSON.—Arrd 13th Nov 1869; Attd to N W P 19th Nov 1869; Asst Magt Mirath 13th Dec 1869; Benares 26th May 1870; Basti, 16th Nov 1871; Benares 23rd Apl 1872; Allahabad, 24th Mar 1873; Left N W P 7 Nov 1873; Asst Comr British Burmah 3rd gr, 4th Sep 1874; Offg 1st Judge S C Court Rangoon. FREDERICK CLENDON DAUKES.—Arrd 8th Nov 1869; Attd to N W P Asst Magt Mirzapur 16th Nov 1869; Allahabad, 7th Dec 1870; Asst Secy to Govt N W P 2nd Apl 1872; Asst Magt Allahabad, 6th Aug 1872; Asst Secy to Govt N W P 13th Apl 1873; 1st Asst Secy 30th Aug 1873; Offg Under Secy 16th Sept 1873; 1st Asst Secy 16th Oct 1873; Asst Set Offr 3rd gr, Banda, 28th Nov 1873; Services placed at the disposal of the Govt of India Foreign Dept Dec 1873; Left N W P 23rd Dec 1873; Sr Attache Foreign Dept G I 4th Sep 1874; Offg Asst Secy Foreign Dept 17th Mar 1876; Under Secy Govt of India Home, Dept 14th Dec 1877; Furl 1 year 13th May 1878; Under Secy Home Dept 12th May 1879.

JAMES PRATT.—Arrd 12th Oct 1869—Asst Magt, Jessore, 11th Nov 1869—Passed the lower standard, 22nd May 1871—Passed the higher standard, 12th Mar 1872—Asst Magt, Deoghur sub-divn, Sonthal Pergs, 26th Apr 1872—Mymensingh, 31st May 1872—Tipperah, 2nd Apr 1873—Offg Jt.-Magt, 2nd gr, 1st July 1873—Asst Magt, 1st Feb 1874—Mymensingh, 15th Aug 1874—Offg Jt.-Magt, 2nd gr, 1st Mar 1875—1st gr, 11th May 1875—2nd gr, 8th Dec 1875—1st gr, 7th Mar 1876—Offg Magt, Mymensingh, 1st Feb 1877—Offg Jt.-Magt, 1st gr, 1st Mar 1877—Offg Magt, Mymensingh, 20th Apr 1877—Offg Jt.-Magt, 1st gr, 15th May 1877—Furl from 11th Mar 1878.

FRANCIS WILLIAM BADCOCK.—Arrd 24th Nov 1869—Asst Magt, Bardwan, 8th Dec 1869—Passed the lower standard, 22nd May 1871—Asst Magt, Bhagulpore, 10th Nov 1871—in charge of the sub-divn of Mudheppoorah, 15th Dec 1871—Monghyr, 28th June 1872—Passed the higher standard, 30th July 1872—in charge of the sub-divn of Begosserai, Monghyr, 20th Sep 1872—Bhagulpore, 20th Nov 1872—Offg Jt.-Magt, 2nd gr, 1st July 1873—On spl duty as Settl Officer of Bhagulpore, Monghyr and Purneab, 18th July 1873—On settl duty at Bhagulpore, 17th Oct 1873—Asst Magt, on settl duty, 20th Nov 1873—Offg Jt.-Magt, on settl duty, 29th Nov 1873—Asst Magt, 1st Dec 1873—Offg Jt.-Magt, 2nd gr, 12th Feb 1875—1st gr, 11th May 1875—1st gr, Chittagong, 17th Oct 1875—2nd gr, 27th Nov 1875—Asst Magt, 4th Jan 1876—Offg Jt.-Magt, 2nd gr, 14th Feb 1876—1st gr, 1st Apr 1876—2nd gr, 24th Dec 1876—Asst Magt, 2nd Jan 1877—Backergunge, 14th May 1877—Offg Jt.-Magt, 1st gr, 18th July 1877—Furl from 8th Dec 1877 to 30th Dec 1878—On spl duty in the office of the Board of Rev, Calcutta, 18th Jan 1879—Asst Magt, 24-Pergs., 10th Mar 1879—Offg Jt.-Magt, 2nd gr, 18th Mar 1879—Offg Inspr.-Genl of Regtn, 30th Mar 1879—Offg Magt and Dy Collr, Howrah, 3rd gr, 19th July 1879.

THOMAS JAMES MURRAY.—Arrd. 31st Oct. 1869—Asst. Magt., Maldah, 17th Nov. 1869—Moorshedabad, 23rd May 1870—In charge of the sub-divn. of Jamunkand, 30th Nov. 1871—In charge of the City Moorshedabad sub-divn., 30th Sept. 1872—Asst. Commr., 1st gr., but to continue Asst. Secy. to the Chief Commr., 25th Sept. 1878—Furl. for one year from 22nd Aug. 1879.

GEORGE DOUGLAS BURGESS.—Arrd. 9th Nov. 1870—Apptd. to British Burma Commn.—Posted to Thayetmyo, 8th Dec. 1870—Passed the lower standard in Burmese, Law, and Rev., 22nd Nov. 1871—Posted to Allamgyo, 21st Mar. 1872—Apptd. ex-officio Asst Collr. of Customs at Allamgyo, 4th July 1872—Passed the higher standard in Law and Rev., 21st Nov. 1872—Magt. of 1st class, 1st Jan. 1873—Magt. of the Allamgyo sub-divn., 1st Jan. 1873—Magt. of Myedai divn. of Thayetmyo dist., 1st Aug. 1873—Ag. CHARLES EDWARD BUCKLAND.—Arrd. 29th Nov. 1870—Asst Magt, Howrah, Dec 1870—24-Pergs, 14th June 1871—Passed the lower standard, 4th Nov. 1871—Attaché, Foreign Dept, 17th Nov. 1871—Offg. Under-Secy to the Govt of India, Home Dept, 9th May 1878—Priv Secy to the President of the Council of the Govr-Genl of India, 22nd Nov 1878—Offg Under-Secy to the Govt of India, Home Dept, 21st Dec 1878—Offg Press Commr with the Govt of India, 1st Feb 1879.

STEPHEN JACOB.—Arrd. 16th Nov. 1871—Asst Commr, 3rd class, Nagpore, 17th Nov. 1871—3rd class, Chunda, 7th Apl. 1872—Regr., Judl. Commr's. Court, Cen. Prov., 4th Oct. 1873—Asst. III.
NORTH WEST PROVINCES.

[Note.—All Officers before whose names there appears an asterisk have been allowed the privilege of taking their annuity and furlough a year sooner than they would otherwise be entitled to do, in consideration of their services in the Lucknow garrison.]

Class I.—31 Years' Standing.

1839. Hon'ble Francis Boyle Pearson.—Arrd., 27th Dec. 1840; attached to N.W.P., 25th June 1841; Asst. Magt., Ghazipur, 27th Aug. 1841; Offg. Jt. Magt., Fatehpur, 1st June 1842; Asst. Magt., Fatehpur, 30th June 1844; Offg. Jt. Magt., 28th Oct. 1844; Offg. Jt. Magt., Kalpi (in Hamirpur), 1st Mar. 1845; Jt. Magt., Fatehpur, 15th Feb. 1846; Offg. Jt. Magt., Kalpi, Feb. 1846; Jt. Magt., Kalpi, 30th Jan. 1847; Settlt. Officer, trans-Sutlej territory, Apl. 1849; services at disposal of Govt. N.W.P., Mar. 1850; Regtr., Sadr. Diwani and Nizamat Adalat, N.W.P., 6th Apl. 1850; Offg. Magt., Allahabad, 16th Apl. 1853; Magt., Allahabad, 10th May 1853; furl. to Eur. from 21st Feb. 1855 to 10th Nov. 1857; on subsistence allow 11th Nov. to 22nd Dec. 1857; Offg. Judge, Benares, 23rd Dec. 1857; Offg. Magt., Ghazipur, 3rd Feb. 1858; Offg. Judge, Sangor, 13th Mar. 1858; Magt., Gorakhpur, 17th Apl. 1858; Offg. Judge, Sangor, Oct. 1858; Cawnpore, 26th Apl. 1859; on special duty as Comr. for compensation in the Agra Divn. from 15th Nov. 1859; Judge, Cawnpore, 4th Apl. 1860; on special duty at Lucknow, 12th Sept. 1860; Judge, Cawnpore, 28th Sept. 1860; Offg. Judge of the Sadr. Diwani and Nizamat Adalat, N.W.P., 1st Sept. 1862; Offg. Extra Judge of the Sadr. Diwani and Nizamat Adalat, 23rd Dec. 1862; Judge of the Sadr. Diwani and Nizamat Adalat, 1st Apl. 1864; Judge of the H.Ct. N.W.P., June 1866; leave on M.C. from 4th Dec. 1869 to 27th July 1871; Judge H.Ct. 1st Aug. 1871.

1844. Hon'ble Robert Spankie.—Arrd. 13th July 1844; attached to N.W.P., July 1845; Asst. Magt. Mainpuri, 16th Sep. 1845; furl. on M.C. 9th Apl. 1846 to 3rd Dec. 1847; Asst., under the Comr. V.
CENTRAL PROVINCES.

CHARLES GRANT.—Arrd 8th Apr 1858, Attd to N W P 7th Jan 1859; Asst Magt Agra, 7th Mar 1859, Saharanpur 14th May 1860; Placed in charge of Settl duties July 1861; Asst Magt Muzaffarnagar 1st Mar 1862; Asst Set Offr 3rd gr, May 1862; Mirath Mar 1863; Leave on M C 10th Aug 1863; Services placed at the disposal of the Govt of India for employment in the Set Dept C P Nov 1863; Left N W P 15th Nov 1863, to C P Set Dept 24th Nov 1863; Offg Dy Comr Jabalpur 21st Feb 1865; Furl 1 year 14th Apl 1866; extension 6 months 10th June 1867; Offg Secy to Chf Comr, C P 12th Mar 1868; confirmed 30th Dec 1868; Comr Chattisgarh Divn 9th June 1870; Jabalpur Divn 31st Mar 1871; Furl 20 months 16th Mar 1874; Comr Narbadda Divn 19th Apl 1876 Jabalpur Divn 10th Nov 1876 Narbadda Divn 12th Apl 1877; Offg Judl Comr 27th July 1877; Offg Chief Comr 13th Mar 1879; Addl Member G G's Legisil Council 27th Nov 1879.

ARTHUR PEARSE HOWELL.—Arrd 27th Jan 1858, Attd to N W P 13th May 1859; Asst Magt Mirath 7th Sep 1859; Etawah 20th Aug 1860; Offg Asst Secy to Govt N W P 24th Feb 1862; confirmed 1st Apl 1862; Offg Under Secy 13th Dec 1862; Reverted 20th Mar 1863; Offg Under Secy 1st May 1863; reverted 12th Oct 1863; services placed at the disposal of the Govt of India, Home Dept Apl 1864; left N W P 15th Apl 1864; Under Secy G I Finl and Home Depts 27th Jan 1865; Furl 2 years 15th Mar 1872; Dy Secy G I Dept of Rev and Agric and Offg Secy Home Dept 6th May 1874; Under Secy Home Dept Offg Secy 6th Nov 1874; Comr Jabalpur Divn 8th June 1877; Offg as Home Secy to P W D Famine Branch 13th Mar 1878; Comr Jabalpur Divn 1st Nov 1878; Offg Judl Comr, 1st Dec 1879; reverted 1st Mar 1880.

CHARLES HAUKE'S TOD CROSTHWAIT.—Arrd 29th Dec 1857; Attd to N W P 11th Nov 1858; Asst Magt Banda 27th Dec 1858; Offg Jt Magt Bareilly 21st Mar 1861; Budaun 11th May 1863; Offg Asst Set Offr 3rd gr, Meerut 18th Jan 1864, confirmed 2nd gr, 10th Apl 1864; Offg Jt Magt also Set Offr Ethai 3rd June 1865; Asst Set Offr 1st gr, 1st Jan 1866; furl to Eur from 14th Feb 1868 to 12th Nov 1869; Asst Magt Allahabad 23rd Nov 1869; Set Offr 2nd gr, Etawah 1st Apl 1870; in charge of Set Moradabad Aug 1872 1st gr, 1st Apl 1873; Moradabad Jan 1874; leave to Eur on private affairs from 30th Mar to 22nd Sept 1874; Set Offr 1st gr, Moradabad 2nd Oct 1874; Offg Secy to Bd of Rev N W P 29th Mar 1875; confirmed 26th Feb 1877; Services placed at disposal of G I in Home Dept Mar 1877; Offg Comr Jabalpur C P 6th Apl 1877; Comr Nagpur, 20th July 1877; Offg at Jabalpur, Offg Judl Comr 25th July 1878.

CHARLES WILLIAM McMINN.—Arrd 21st Jan 1863; Attd to N W P 7th July 1864; Asst Magt Banaras, 3rd Aug 1864; Offg 3rd class Asst Comr Lucknow 13th Feb 1865; Hardoi May 1865; confirmed June 1865; Offg Asst Set Offr Setapur 18th Sept 1865; Hardoi, wpl 1867, confirmed Partabgarh 18th May 1867; Offg Asst Comr 1st gr, (on Set duty) Partabgarh 21st July 1868; Offg Set Offr Bara Banki 23rd Dec 1868; Kheri, 13th Oct 1869; Asst Comr 2nd gr, (Offg Set Offr) 24th Mar 1871; Kheri, 22nd Mar 1872; on spl duty at Lucknow for compln of the Oudh Gazetteer 6th July 1872; on spl duty to Simla 4th July 1873; Prov'l Gazetteer Oudh 13th Oct 1873; Offg Asst Comr, 1st gr, 1st June 1874; Lucknow 18th Nov 1874; confirmed 23rd Apl 1875; Offg Dy Comr 3rd gr Unao 27th Apl 1875; Asst Comr 1st gr, Unao, 30th Nov 1875; Furl to Eur 21st Apl 1876; Asst Comr 1st gr, Sultanpur 5th Apl 1877; Offg Jt Magt 1st gr Agra, 12th Sept 1877, conf 29th Nov 1877; Dy Comr 3rd cl Raipur C P 4th Feb 1879; furl 1st Apl 1880.
VI.
ASSAM.

SEPTIMUS OTTER BARNES RIDSDALE.—Arrd 10th Oct 1862; attd to N.W.P. 11th Mar 1863; Asst Magt Mirath, 1st Apl 1863; Aligarh, 17th July 1865; Mirath, 17th Aug 1865; Asst Set Offr 4th gr, Ajmere and Mhairwara, 12th Jan 1867; 3rd gr Nov 1867; 3rd gr, Gorakhpur and Basti, 19th Jan 1869; 2nd gr 6th Mar 1869; Set Offr 3rd gr, Etah, 14th June 1870; also in charge of Set, Hamirpur, Aug 1872; Furl 26th Feb 1873; Set Offr Hamirpur, 7th Nov 1873; Offg Magt 26th Sep 1874; services placed at the disposal of Govt of India, Home Dept Apl 1876; left N.W.P. 26th Apl 1876; Secy to Cf Comr, Assam, 18th May 1876; Offg Comr Assam Valley Dists 1st Apl 1880.

CHARLES DONOVAN.—Arrd 11th Jan 1863; attd to N.W.P 12th Mar 1364; Asst 3rd Apl 1864; Muzaffarnagar, 2nd June 1868; Offg Jt Magt 2nd gr, 7th Apl 1871; Asst Magt 5th Dec 1871; Offg Jt Magt 2nd gr, 28th Mar 1872; 2nd gr, Dehra Dun, 4th May 1872; 1st gr, 20th Aug 1872; Asst Magt Dehra Dun, 2nd Feb 1873; Agra, 23rd Mar 1873; Offg Jt Magt 1st gr, 1st May 1873; Asst Magt Agra, 1st Dec 1875; Offg Jt Magt 22nd Apl 1876; Etah Dist 2nd Sep 1876; Offg Jt Magt 2nd gr, Agra, 4th Nov 1876; 1st gr, 19th Mar 1877; Muzaffarnagar, 12th Apl 1877; Offg Magt 16th May 1876; Offg Jt Magt 1st gr, Muzaffarnagar, 15th July 1878; Dp Comr 1st gr, Assam, 5th Sept 189 to Kamrup.

BRITISH BURMAH.

SERVICES.

1856. CHARLES UMPHEASTON AITCHISON, C.S.I., LL.D.—Jd. the service 26th June 1856; arrd., 24th Sept. 1856; passed in Persian and Hindee; Asst Commr Punjab, 4th May 1857; Personal Asst. to the Judl. Commr., Punjab, 22nd July 1858; Under Secy. to Govt. of India, Forn. Dept., 25th Nov. 1859; Dy. Commr., 2nd class, Punjab, 27th Jan. 1865; Ag. Commr. Lahore divn., 16th Aug. 1867; Ag. Secy. to Govt. of the Punjab, 23rd Nov. 1867; Ag. Secy. to Govt. of India, Forn. Dept., 25th Apr. 1868; furl. on medi. cert. to Europe from 4th Aug. 1868 to 27th Aug. 1869; Ag. Secy. to the Govt. of India, Forn. Dept., 8th Sept. 1869; Dy. Commr., 1st class, Punjab, and Ag. Secy. to Govt. of India, Forn. Dept., 1st May 1870; Secy. to Govt. of India, Forn. Dept., 1st Aug., 1870; furl. to Europe from 11th Feb. 1876 spl. duty, 11th Oct. 1877; Secy. to Govt. of India, Forn. Dept., 24th Oct. 1877; Chief Commr., British Burma, 31st Mar. 1878.

ROBERT JOSEPH CROSTHWAITA, B.A. (Barrister-at-law).—Jd. the service, 30th July 1863; arrd. 30th Oct. 1863; attached to North-Western Provs., 12th July 1864; Asst Magt., Meerut, 10th Aug. 1864; Bulandshahr, 17th July 1865; furl to Europe on medi. cert from 24th Apr. 1867 to 9th Dec. 1868; Asst Magt Jaunpur, 26th Dec. 1868; Offg Jt Magt 2nd gr, Jaunpur, 7th Jan. 1869; Budaun, 10th Feb. 1870 on spl. duty on the Rev Committee at Naini Tal from 15th July to 29th Oct. 1872; Offg Jt Magt 1st gr (on spl. duty), 16th Sep. 1872; 2nd gr (on spl. duty), 4th Oct. 1872; 2nd gr, in charge Pilibhit sub-divn., 7th Nov. 1872; 1st gr, Pilibhit, 8th Sep. 1873; 2nd gr, Pilibhit, 28th Sep. 1873; Subdt Judge, Judge of the Small Cause Ct, and Asst Supdt, Dehra Dun, 27th Dec. 1873; Offg Jt Magt 1st gr, 6th May 1874; 2nd gr, 27th June 1874; Jt Magt 2nd gr, Offg 1st gr, 28th July 1874; 2nd gr, 3rd Nov. 1874; Judge Small Cause Court, Allahabad, 29th Mar. 1875; furl to Europe on medi. cert from 9th June 1876 to 7th Nov. 1877; Regr. High Court, North-Western Provs., 17th Nov. 1877; services placed at the disposal of the Govt of India, Home Dept., Nov. 1878; Offg Judl Commr, British Burma, 2nd Dec. 1878.

1864. JOHN JARDINE.—B.O.C.S.—Jd the service, 30th July 1864; arrd. 30th Oct. 1864; placed under the Collr of Tanna, 9th Nov. 1864; Ahmednagar, 10th Jan. 1865; Asst Magt, Dharwar, 3rd Apr. 1865; Supy Asst Magt, Dharwar, 9th Sept. 1865; Supy Third Asst Kanara, 12th Jan. 1866; Ag Second Asst Kanara, 16th Aug. 1866; Asst Judge Satara, 20th May 1867; Ag Asst Judge Poona, 18th July 1867; Satara, 1st Oct. 1867; Ag Dharwar, 17th Dec. 1867; confirmed 22nd June 1868; Second Asst Magt, Ahmednagar, 21st Oct. 1868; Ag Second Asst Poona, 18th Nov. 1868; Ag Under Secy to the Govt in the Pol, Judl, and Edl Depts, and Secy to the Legislative Council 17th June 1869; on spl leave to Europe from 14th Nov. 1869 Ag Under Secy to Govt in the Pol, Judl, and Edl Depts, and Ag Secy to the Council 1st Feb. 1870; Ag First Pol Asst in Kattywar, 23rd May 1871; Asst Judge Satara, Ag First Pol Asst at Kattywar, 18th Dec. 1871; Ag Judl Asst in Kattywar and Pol Asst of Nawanagar and Dhrol States 7th June 1872; confirmed 2nd June 1873; Ag Regr. of the High Ct, Appl Side, Bombay, 13th Oct. 1873; Secy, Baroda Commr for the trial of His Highness Malhar Rao Gaekwar, 17th Feb. to 18th May 1875; Ag Regr. of the High Ct, Appl Side, 19th May to 12th Oct. 1875; Ag Judge, Ratnagiri, 19th Oct. 1875 to 20th Feb. 1876; Tanna, 29th Feb. to 20th June 1876; Khandesh, 16th July 1876 to 1st Feb. 1877; Secy to the Delegates of the Govt of India for a commercial treaty with Portugal, 1st Mar. 1877; Ag Dy Secy to the Govt of India, Leg Dept, also Secy to the Delegates, 5th Apr. 1877; Ag Secy to Govt in the Pol, Judl, Edl, Secret, and Persian Depts from 27th Nov. 1877 to 29th Jan. 1878; Judl Commr, British Burma, 22nd Feb. 1878.

1864. GEORGE JAMES SPENCE HODGKINSON.—Jd the service, 8th Aug. 1864; arrd. 25th Nov. 1864; Asst Magt Saran, 25th Nov. 1865; Tirhoot, 29th Apr. 1867; in charge of Tejapore sub-divn.; Ag Jt Magt 2nd gr, 20th July 1868; Ag Jt Magt and Collr, 2nd gr, Tirhoot 31st Aug. 1869; Tajpore sub-divn. 22nd Nov. 1869; Tirhoot 30th March.
1870; Manager, Hutwa Estate, 23rd Jan 1872; furl for two years, 30th Nov 1874; Ag Jt Magt 1st gr, Hooghly, 8th Dec 1876; Ag Dy Collr of Customs, Calcutta, 23rd Feb 1877; Asst. Magt. 28th Feb 1877; Jt-Magt 2nd, gr, 12th March 1877, Ag Magt Moorshedabad; tempy Agent to the Govr-Genl at Moorshedabad, 24th June 1877; Ag Magt 2nd gr, 6th Aug 1877; 3rd gr 24th Nov 1877; 2nd gr 4th Dec 1877; 3rd gr, 7th Feb 1878; 2nd gr Saram, 1st Apl, 1878; Jt Magt 1st gr Ag Magt 2nd gr, Saram; 29th Apl 1878, 1st gr Offg Commr of Arakan divn, British Burma, 12th Dec. 1878.

1870. GEORGE DOUGLAS BURGESS.—Jd the service, 26th Sept 1870; arrd 9th Nov 1870; appd to British Burma Commr, 29th Nov 1870; posted to Thayetmyo, 2nd Dec 1870; passed in lower standard in Burmese, Law, and Aev,—two latter with credit, 22nd Nov 1871; posted to Allanmyo, 21st Mar 1872; ex-officio Asst Collr of Custom at Allanmyo, 4th July 1872; passed higher standard in Law and Rev with credit,, 21st Nov 1872; Magt 1st class, Allanmyo sub-divn 1st Jany 1873; Madai divn of Thayetmyo dist, 1st Aug 1873; Ag Dy Commr Thayetmyo dist, 16th Oct 1873; Justice of the Peace, 25th Feb 1874; Offg Asst Commr 2nd gr 3rd July 1874; 1st gr, from 1st to 26th Feb 1875; accompanied escort to meet Messrs. Grosvenor, Baber, and Davenport returning from the Yunnan Mission, Apl, 1876; Asst Commr, 2nd gr, 16th Sept 1876; Offg Depy Commr, 4th gr, Rangoon dist, 13th Oct 1877; Bassein dist, 6th Nov 1877; Offg Secy to the Chief Commr, 1st Jan 1879

1870. GEORGE LEVER WEIDEMAN.—Jd the service, 2nd Oct 1870; arrd in Calcutta 22nd Nov 1870; arrd in Rangoon, 7th Dec 1870; placed under Dy Commr, Moulmein 10th Dec 1870; Asst Commr, Thatone, 2nd Sept 1871; Toungoo, 12th Aug 1872 Rangoon, 17th Apl 1873; Bassein, 14th Feb 1874; Pantanaw, 6th Dec 1875; Mengyee, 15th Nov 1876; on forest settlement, 15th Dec 1877; Asst Commr, Poungday, 20th Feb 1878; Mengyee, 19th Mar 1878; Gyobingonk, 17th June 1878; 2nd Gr 3rd Aug 1878 Henzada dist, 19th Sept 1878.

ROBERT HOPE PILCHER.—Arrd 14th Sept 1871; Asst Commr, Jubbulpore, Central Provs, Nov 1871; Shwe-gyene, British Burma, Apl 1878; Toungoo, Apl 1874; Shwe-gyene, May 1874; Sittoung sub-divn, July 1874; Karen Hill Tracts, Mar 1875; Asst Aesident Mandalay, Nov 1875; Jr Secy to Chief Commr, 12th June 1877.

1872. HENRY LOUIS ST. BARBE.—Joined the service, 1st July 1872; arrd 17th Sep 1872; Asst Magt Krishnagar, 24th Oct 1872; Supy Asst Commr, British Burma, 25th Feb 1873; in tempy charge of Toungoo dist, 5th Mar to 8th Apl 1874; Offg 1st Judge, Small Cause Court, Rangoon, 3rd Aug 1875; in charge of Ngathain-gyoung sub-divn, 11th Nov 1875; Asst Commr, Offg 3rd gr, 16th Dec 1875; Offg 2nd gr, 20th June 1876; apptd to Rangoon Seort, 18th Dec 1876; Offg Pol Asst 1st class, 26th June 1877; Offg Pol Agent, 3rd class, 31st May 1878.
